bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the Cornwell painting in progress, proposed changes to the painting, and the possibility of producing a second painting to appease critics in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1941
div1.opener:
answered long hand
comment paint on bldg
Table & chairs on lawn
K & Moran Standing
sent come ts
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
March 4th, 1941
Dr. Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I have gone over both your letters and the one from
General Truby, with Mr. Cornwell.

I agree with you that I think there is a certain
amount of inconsistency in General Truby's suggestions. I question if
we will get General Wood in the painting. I am afraid that our
artist's patience will not last long enough to include another principal
figure in which a good portrait will be necessary. He is quite agree-
able to placing Moran and Kissinger in the background.

As you say, I think General Truby's suggestion for
the placing and arrangement of the picture would be rather static.
Mr. Cornwell has made a sketch in which he shows figures standing at
various levels on the steps of the Officer's quarters. Carroll and
Lazear are seated at a table on the ground at the edge of the steps.
It is quite true that this probably did not happen, but as we have
said before, neither was Major Reed there when it happened. It gives
the artist a chance to place heads at several levels; an arrangement
he is desirous of having.

At the risk of sounding pedantic, I'm going to
write a little on the art side of our problem:

First, we must have a fine painting. If we wished
to get what was merely a photographic reproduction of a particular
incident that took place in 1900 with all details accurately portrayed,
we would have to get a cheaper artist, and then we would have a mere
pictoral record of historical data. However, such pictures have
little or no value in the fine arts world. One of the reasons we are
using Cornwell is that the pictures must have a permanent fine arts
value.

Mr. Cornwell must look upon the material in this
story as a symphony composer looks upon melodic and rhythmic ideas.
The composer takes from his available material what he finds useful
in creating a piece of music. The painter has to take from our
story what he can use to create a symphony in color and design.
Thus, in order to get a fine painting we cannot tie his hands too
closely.

To go back to the subject of placing the figures
on the porch: He tells me that to paint likenesses from the avail-
able photographs that he has, to place the figures on the porch, would
be an artistic lie which he would be ashamed to exhibit. These heads
are all photographed with a light that comes down almost vertically -
as the light did come down in the old fashioned photographic studios.
The light which would strike the faces on the porch would be light
reflected from the ground and would entirely change the contour of the
faces. This he could do only if he had the actual people posing for
him under light from this latter source.

I think that you agree with us that what we want
from this painting is a representation of the spirit of the truth.
If we had had a photographer in 1900 going about taking photographs
of everything taking place, they would all be correct representations
of what was happening at any one time, but I question if any of them
would give posterity a comprehensive picture of what the study of
yellow fever meant -- Our painting must be a synthesis.

As to satisfying the Cubans -- it is quite possible
that we will complete a second painting using the version which you
saw in Rochester; but it cannot be done until next year. I say, it
is possible, because Mr. Cornwell's fee for doing the job is not in
our budget this year, and next year is always anybody's guess. I am
afraid we will have to worry about the Cubans later. Frankly, our
total business down there today wouldn't pay for the cost of a canvas
by Cornwell in five years.

We are having the two sketches which you saw,
tastefully framed so that should you wish to take them to Havana, you
will be welcome to do so. I am hoping that you will be coming through
New York and spending an hour or two with Mr. Cornwell in his studio.
Will this be possible?

As to General Truby's letter: it contains
much information which is of great value to Mr. Cornwell, and I am
going to write him a letter of appreciation tomorrow.

I am inclosing a copy of a feature story which
has run in a number of newspapers around the country. I am afraid
the reporter did not quote Mr. Cornwell very accurately. In the first
place, Cornwell cannot drink more than three Daiquiris under any cir-
cumstances -- and to read the story you would think he was tight all
the time he was in Havana! This publicity story is good only
in that along with disseminating a considerable amount of misinformation,
it does serve to interest the public to a degree in the painting of
the yellow fever investigation!!
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George Kellogg G.A. Kellogg/fr
